Capacity Development Technical Assistance (CDTA) 
December 2012 
 
 
 
Mongolia: Strengthening the Anti-Money Laundering 
Regime

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) was developed following initial discussions between the 
Government of Mongolia and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in November 2011 and May 
2012, and the receipt of a formal request from the Bank of Mongolia on 31 May 2012. Pursuant 
to consultations between the East Asia Department and the Office of the General Counsel, a 
reconnaissance mission was fielded on 3–5 July 2012 and a fact-finding mission was fielded on 
5–6 September 2012. The aide-mémoire of the fact-finding mission has been confirmed by the 
government. The design and monitoring framework of the TA is in Appendix 1.1 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  A key constraint in the anti-money-laundering and combating the financing of terrorism 
(AML/CFT)  regime  in  Mongolia  is  the  level  of  capacity  in  its  law  enforcement  agencies, 
prosecutors,  and  judiciary  in  the  investigation  and  prosecution  of  money  laundering  and 
terrorism financing offenses.  
3.  Based on discussions with the various authorities, first, it is noted that concerns exist 
regarding  the  influx  of  illegal  money  from  abroad  during  the  current  vibrant  economic 
development. The authorities are generally concerned about the need to address the new 
trends  and  typologies  of  potential  illegal  activities  in  Mongolia  in  addition  to  the  range  of 
proceeds of illegal activities that may be laundered in Mongolia, such as corruption, smuggling, 
and tax evasion.2  
4.  Second, a lack of a common understanding appears to exist on how to approach money 
laundering offenses. This is due to uncertainty regarding the elements of the money laundering 
offense in the criminal code. While work is ongoing on the revision of the money laundering 
offense, the general view of the authorities is that a common understanding of the approach to 
the  money  laundering  offense  is  important  for  investigation  and  prosecution  of  money 
laundering activities detected by the authorities. The authorities have fewer concerns about the 
terrorism financing offense, as terrorism financing activities appear to be less prevalent in 
Mongolia. Capacity constraints remain, given the nature of terrorism financing (which is different 
from traditional crimes) and the proposed TA will take this into account.  
5.  Third, some of the authorities recognize that there should be specialized investigators 
and  prosecutors  for  economic  crimes,  including  money  laundering  and  terrorism  financing 
offenses. There should, at any rate, be training for officers engaged in these activities, as the 
legal and evidentiary issues and investigation techniques involved are different from those for 
traditional crimes. Moreover, such training should be systematic given the capacity constraints 
across the authorities.  
6.  More generally, the Financial Action Task Force (FATF) has identified Mongolia as a 
country with strategic deficiencies in its AML/CFT regime, given its level of compliance with 
AML/CFT international standards. Other areas of weakness are deficiencies in the formulation 
of the money laundering and terrorism financing offenses in the criminal law and the capacity of 
the  financial  regulators  in  overseeing  AML/CFT  compliance,  for  which  the  government  is 
receiving  support  from  other  development  partners  and  donors.  Mongolia  is  one  of  the

2  Asia/Pacific  Group  on  Money  Laundering.  2007.  APG  Mutual  Evaluation  Report  on  Mongolia. 
http://www.apgml.org/documents/docs/17/Mongolia%20Mutual%20Evaluation%202007%20-%20Final%20.pdf

2   
22 countries on the so-called “grey list” issued by the FATF3, which means that parties wishing 
to do business in Mongolia are required to pay special attention to risks related to money 
laundering and terrorism financing, which increase the transaction costs. It has also agreed an 
action plan with the FATF for addressing the deficiencies. 
7.  The weaknesses in Mongolia’s AML/CFT regime are material, as it is regarded as a 
country with significant money laundering and terrorism financing risks (footnote 2, paras. 39–
59).  For  example,  corruption,  smuggling,  and  tax  evasion  have  been  identified  as  crimes 
generating significant proceeds in Mongolia. Similarly, there were suggestions that Mongolia 
may be a staging post for drug trafficking in the region. Mongolia also has a predominantly 
cash-based economy and a large informal sector, which makes it more vulnerable to money 
laundering and terrorism financing risks.   
8.  There  have  been  some  investigations  of  money  laundering  and  terrorism  financing 
offenses, but no successful prosecution to date. This is why the broad range of authorities that 
have responsibilities for AML/CFT think that systematic capacity development in investigation 
and prosecution is important for Mongolia at this stage. 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA will provide systematic capacity development for the authorities responsible for 
investigation and prosecution of money laundering and terrorism financing offenses. These 
authorities are primarily the Bank of Mongolia, the General Police Department, the General 
Intelligence Agency, the Independent Authority Against Corruption, the General Prosecutor’s 
Office, and the judiciary. 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The impact of the TA will be an enhanced AML/CFT regime for Mongolia. This will 
contribute  to  Mongolia  being  taken  off  the  FATF  “grey  list,”  provided  that  other  areas  of 
weakness are addressed. The outcome of the TA will be government authorities with better 
capacity, both within individual authorities as well as part of the national AML/CFT efforts, to 
carry out investigation and prosecution of money laundering and terrorism financing offenses. 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will support capacity development for about 40 officers from the participating 
authorities over 2 years. These officers will be trained in  money laundering and terrorism 
financing trends and typologies, investigation techniques, legal and evidentiary issues, and case 
preparation for investigation and prosecution, which will be applied in their operational work. 
About 10 such officers (selected based on good performance on the program) will participate in 
a short secondment to their counterpart agencies in a suitable ADB member country. The TA 
will  also  support  preparation  of  a  paper  on  the  issues  and  challenges  in  the  design  and 
implementation of an AML/CFT capacity development program using Mongolia as an example.  
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $400,000 equivalent, of which $360,000 will be financed on

a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund for Regional Trade and Financial Security Initiative,4 and 
administered by ADB. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
13.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of staff, organization of 
conferences  and  workshops  (including  the  costs  of  venues  and  meals  as  well  as  the 
accommodation and transport costs of the participants) and printing of training materials, and 
other in-kind contributions. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
14.  The Bank of Mongolia will be the executing agency and responsible for coordinating with 
the other participating authorities in the implementation of the TA. 
15.  The TA will support the use of four individual consultants for a total of about 9 person-
months (two international consultants) and 4 person-months (two national consultants). A pair of 
international and national consultants will cover the legal aspects of the capacity development 
program. A pair of international and national consultants will cover the law enforcement aspects 
of the capacity development program. These consultants will design the capacity development 
program in consultation with the government and ADB. Training and hands-on mentoring will be 
delivered by the consultants in Mongolia. The international consultants will also prepare a paper 
on  the  issues  and  challenges  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  an  AML/CFT  capacity 
development program using Mongolia as an example. The outline terms of reference for the 
consultants are in Appendix 3. These consultants will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time).  
16.  The TA will also support a short secondment for 10 participants (selected based on good 
performance on the program) to their counterpart agencies in a suitable ADB member country. It 
will  also  cover  the  costs  of  interpretation  and  translation,  and  other  miscellaneous  costs. 
Disbursement under the TA will be in accordance with the Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
17.  The TA will be implemented from 1 January 2013 to 31 December 2014. 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $360,000 to the Government 
of Mongolia to be financed on a grant basis by the Cooperation Fund for Regional Trade and 
Financial Security Initiative for Strengthening the Anti-Money Laundering Regime, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  7 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Legal  experts  (1  international  consultant,  4  person-months;  1  national  consultant, 
2 person-months). The consultants will design and implement the legal aspects of the capacity 
development program, which will include the following: 
(i)  Examining the legal and evidentiary issues in the investigation and prosecution of 
money  laundering  and  terrorism  financing  offenses.  This  takes  into  account 
national law requirements and international standards, including amendment of 
existing national laws to meet international standards. 
(ii)  Preparing training materials for national workshops and delivering the training. 
This includes taking into account feedback from the participating authorities and 
the  National  Cooperation  Council,  lessons  from  the  basic  training,  and 
amendments to the existing national laws. 
(iii)  Preparing  indicators  for  evaluating  participant  performances  (including  their 
improved competency in anti-money-laundering and combating the financing of 
terrorism [AML/CFT]) under the program and carrying out the evaluation. 
 
2.  In addition to the above, the international consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Provide hands-on mentoring to the prosecutors under the capacity development 
program. Such mentoring involves the sharing of practical experiences but not 
the provision of specific advice in operational matters. 
(ii)  Assist in setting up the secondment during the advanced training phase of the 
program.  
(iii)  Prepare  a  short  paper  on  the  issues  and  challenges  in  the  design  and 
implementation of an AML/CFT capacity development program from the legal 
perspective. 
 
3.  Law  enforcement  experts  (1  international  consultant,  5  person-months;  1  national 
consultant, 2 person-months). The consultants will design and implement the law enforcement 
aspects of the capacity development program, which will include: 
(i)  Examining the practical aspects of the investigation and prosecution of money 
laundering and terrorism financing offenses. This takes into account national law 
requirements  and  international  standards,  including  amendment  of  existing 
national laws to meet international standards. 
(ii)  Preparing training materials for national workshops and delivering the training. 
This includes taking into account feedback from the participating authorities and 
the  National  Cooperation  Council,  lessons  from  the  basic  training,  and 
amendments to the existing national laws. 
(iii)  Preparing  indicators  for  evaluating  participant  performances  (including  their 
improved competency in AML/CFT) under the program and carrying out the 
evaluation. 
 
4.  In addition to the above, the international consultant will do the following: 
(i)  Provide hands-on mentoring to the law enforcement officers under the capacity 
development  program.  Such  mentoring  involves  the  sharing  of  practical 
experiences but not the provision of specific advice in operational matters. 
(ii)  Assist in setting up the secondment during the advanced training phase of the 
program.  
(iii)  Prepare  a  short  paper  on  the  issues  and  challenges  in  the  design  and 
implementation  of  an  AML/CFT  capacity  development  program from the  law 
enforcement perspective.
